questions.text: During a developmental assessment in the pediatric clinic, you observe a child who runs adeptly and climbs stairs with one foot per step. Recalling the lecture from your pediatric mentor on milestone development, you consider what the next stage of stair climbing development is. At what age is a child expected to develop the ability to climb steps using alternate feet?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3 years

 

Option B.

 

The child can ride tricycle, climbing upstairs with alternate feet by 3 years of age.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. By the age of 2 years the child can run well, climb upstairs and downstairs with one step at a time

 

Option C. The child can start hopping and goes downstairs with alternate feet by the age of 4 years.

 

Option D. The child can start Skipping by the age of 5 years.

 

Educational objective

 

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 43-51.

choices.text: II, III, IV, I
I, II, III, IV
II, I, III, IV
I, II, IV, III

questions.text:
Arrange the following milestones in the correct order of their attainment;

 

I. Build tower of 4 cubes

II. Make simple sentences

III. Drawing a circle

IV. Drawing a rectangle
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) I, II, III, IV

 

Explanation:

 

The age of attainment of the milestones is: -

 

  • Builds a tower of 4 cubes- 18 months
  • Makes simple sentences- 2 years
  • Drawing a circle- 3 years
  • Drawing a rectangle- 4 years

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page 1080

choices.text: Sign of Waving bye – bye while leaving OPD.
Standing without support on the corridors of hospital.
Plays a peek –a – boo with mother and siblings.

questions.text: In the pediatric clinic, a mother presents her 10-month-old child for a routine check-up. During the examination, you find the child to be both active and alert. You decide to evaluate the child's developmental milestones. Based on what you know about the normal development of children at this age, which of the following milestones would you NOT expect to find in a 10-month-old child?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Standing without support on the corridors of hospital.

 

Option C. 

 

Baby stands without support by the age of 1 year not by 9 months.

 

Mile stones achieved in a 10-month-old baby includes.

  • ⁠Immature Pincer grasp - 9 months
  • ⁠Waving bye - bye - 9 months
  • ⁠Plays a peek - a - boo game - 10 months

 

Explanation:

 

Option A, B and D are true regarding the milestones achieved in a 10months old child.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 43-51.

questions.text: A mother brings her infant for vaccination. During the examination, you observe that the infant is capable of moving their head from side to side while tracking a moving object, can lift their head from a prone position approximately 45° off the examining table, smiles responsively when encouraged, and makes cooing sounds. However, the infant is unable to maintain a seated position. Based on these developmental milestones, what is the most likely age of the infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3 months.

 

Option D.

 

A 3-months-old infant can lift his head from prone position, smiles when encouraged, and makes cooing sounds.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. A 1-month-old child cannot hold his neck.

 

Option B. A 6-month-old child can sit with support.
 

Option C. A 2-month-old child cannot hold his neck and make cooing sounds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Developmental milestones of an infant

 

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 43-51.

choices.text: All of the above

questions.text: A mother presents her 2-year-old daughter, Poonguzhali, to the clinic, concerned about her delayed developmental milestones. Upon a thorough examination, you notice not only a delay but also a regression in previously attained milestones. Considering the child's age and the regression observed, you ponder the possible causes. Which of the following conditions is known to potentially result in the regression of developmental milestones?
questions.solution:
Ans.D) All of the above

 

Option D.

 

Regression of milestones can be seen in case of Rett’s syndrome, Autism and Neuromuscular diseases.

Developmental regression, where a child loses previously acquired skills, can be caused by a variety of conditions. Rett’s syndrome is known for a period of normal development followed by a loss of skills, particularly in girls. Autism spectrum disorders can sometimes involve regression, typically noted between 1 and 3 years of age. Neuromuscular diseases can lead to a decline in motor abilities, which can be perceived as developmental regression.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rett’s syndrome - Characterized by early normal development followed by a decrease in head growth rate, loss of purposeful hand skills, and the development of stereotypic hand movements, among other features.

 

Option B. Autism - Some individuals with autism can experience regression, often in language and social skills, after a period of seemingly normal development.

 

Option C. Neuromuscular diseases - These disorders can lead to muscle weakness over time, which might result in the loss of motor skills that a child had previously mastered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Regression of milestones –

 

  • The hallmark of many degenerative disorders is neurological regression.
  • Degenerative diseases of the brain generally cause regression of both motor and cognitive function (global regression).
  • History of only loss of motor milestones — progressive neuromuscular disease — most likely cause.
  • Loss of only language skills — autism — suspected.
  • Regression of both language and motor milestones Rett’s syndrome.
  • A child older than 3 or 4 years of age:
  • Deterioration of gray matter regression with seizures.
  • Deterioration of white matter regression with cognitive slowing and spasticity.
     

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No- 12430.

questions.text: In the pediatric clinic, a mother brings her infant for routine vaccinations. As an intern, you engage in conversation with her, and during the chat, the baby grasps a toy and brings it to their mouth, demonstrating a developmental milestone. The mother, cautious about hygiene, quickly removes the toy from the baby's grasp. This event leads you to reflect on the developmental milestones pertaining to fine motor skills. At what age does an infant typically develop a mature pincer grasp, which allows them to pick up small objects between the thumb and forefinger?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 12 months

 

Option D.

 

Grasping object between thumb and index finger (Mature Pincer grasp) develops by 12 months.

 

 

Immature grasp at 6 months (Palmer grasp)

 

 

 

Intermediate grasp at 8 months, beginning to use radial aspect of the hand

 

 

 

Mature Grasp at 1 yr of age, note the use of thumb and index finger (Pincer grasp)

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. At 7 months of age: baby develop unidextrous approach by 6 months

 

Option A. At 5-6 months of age mouthing develops

 

Option C. At 9 months of age, immature pincer grasp develops.

 

Educational Objective

 

Fine Motor Milestones

  • Birth - Grasp reflex present
  • 3 months - Grasp reflex disappears
  • 4 months - Bidextrous approach
  • 6 months - Unidextrous approach
  • 9 months – Immature pincer grasp
  • 12 — 13 months – Mature Pincer Grasp, Casting appear.
  • 15 months - Feeds himself with cup, slight spillage
  • 18 months - Use of Spoon, slight spillage Scribbles
  • 2 years - Vertical stroke, Turn one page of book at a time
  • 3, 4, 5 years - Universal milestones: -

3 years — draws circle

4 years — draws ‘+’ and square/rectangle

5 years — draws ‘x’ and triangle
 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 43-51.

choices.text: Pincer grasp at 9 months
Walking at 12 months
Babbling at 6 months
Social smile at 6 months

questions.text: An anxious mother presents to the pediatric clinic with her 6-month-old son, concerned because he is not speaking monosyllables like his cousin of the same age. The pediatrician listens to the mother's concerns and then proceeds to educate her about the normal developmental milestones and red flag signs that would warrant further evaluation. Which of the following developmental milestones, if not achieved by the specified age, should be considered a red flag and may indicate a need for further developmental assessment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Social smile at 6 months

 

Option D.

 

A social smile typically develops around 2 months of age. If a child does not exhibit a social smile by 6 months, this would be considered a red flag signifying potential developmental delay or a disorder. Early smiling is part of social interaction and emotional development; therefore, its absence may indicate underlying neurological or developmental issues that need to be addressed.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pincer grasp at 9 months - The pincer grasp usually develops between 9 to 10 months of age. Not achieving this milestone right at 9 months is not necessarily a red flag, as there may be slight variations in development.

 

Option B. Walking at 12 months - It is common for children to start walking independently between 9 to 15 months of age. Not walking precisely at 12 months is not immediately concerning and often does not indicate a developmental problem.

 

Option C. Babbling at 6 months - Babbling typically starts between 4 to 6 months of age. If a child is not babbling by 6 months, it can be a concern, but it is not as significant a red flag.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Important red flag signs in development:

 

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 43-51.
